An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.

A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Does the concept of a/an A-module need to be defined for a definition of a/an Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Group is defined independently of the concept of an A-module. A Group is a set with a binary operation that satisfies three properties: associativity, identity, and inverses. This definition is self-contained and does not require any external structures or concepts such as modules or rings.

On the other hand, an A-module involves a group (specifically an abelian group) and an additional structure of scalar multiplication by elements of a ring A. The definition of an A-module extends the concept of a group by incorporating operations with elements from a ring, but it is not necessary for the basic definition of a group.

Therefore, the definition of a Group does not depend on the concept of an A-module. The existence and properties of groups can be fully understood without reference to modules or any additional algebraic structures.
